name: Theresa P-K.
quote: I am always bargain shopping for food and we rarely go out to eat. Personally, I am always conscience of what I spend and find myself questioning every purchase I make asking: 'Is it worth it?' And with each passing month, it seems we find ourselves looking for ways to cut our spending even more.

name: Dorothy K.
quote: I get about 17,000 per year with Social Security and work, so I cook and eat cheaply. I don't eat out.

name: T.H.H.
quote: The house we rent has no heat, no dish washer, no central air. It has not been updated since the '70s.

name: Jill R.
quote: A little over 6 months ago, I moved to Pomona because it was the lowest rent I could find within an hour bus ride to L.A. It is $900. On the plus side, it has two bedrooms and allows dogs. On the downside. no pool, no AC unit.

name: Barbara G.
quote: Internet, dinners out with friends, movies. Many of the things I took as second nature in my day-to-day life are now all weighed for cost effectiveness.

name: T.H.H.
quote: We shop at .99 cent stores as much as possible. I go to the day-old bread store, and I am waiting for World Harvest food bank to reopen. We have only $300 a month for food for five people.

name: Wendy S.
quote: We hardly ever eat out or buy tickets for entertainment. Rent is not the only large expense we have, but at least we are out of debt.

name: Jill R.
quote: I continue to drive a 15-year-old car with only liability and uninsured motorist coverage.

name: Pablo E.
quote: I have sacrificed purchasing a new computer or a camera, which prevents me from following my dream to be a photographer.

name: Melissa B.
quote: I lived in Glendale, California for 23 years and moved away because I could no longer afford rent. Rent in 1994 was $695 per month. In 2008, I began managing my eight-unit complex so I could stay there at $1,000 per month. I have been on permanent disability since 2001.

name: Marilyn C.
quote: I can't afford to do anything other than eat in cheaply; my social life is the worst since everyone I know has significant others to share their rent costs with.

name: Jonathan C.
quote: We've sacrificed our long-term financial future — any possibility of getting a real house, any possibility of not living paycheck to paycheck.

name: Frank O.
quote: I had to sell my truck because I couldn't afford to pump gas in it weekly anymore.

name: Kevin L.
quote: I now own a house for the simple reason that rent had gotten so high that a $300,000 mortgage is actually cheaper than renting. After figuring in the annual tax break on interest, I pay $500 per month less than it would cost to rent something comparable.

name: Melissa B.
quote: I had a lot of credit card debt, so essentially my income went to paying rent and utilities and credit card payments. I did not buy clothing or household items.

name: Danielle A.
quote: Like many millennials, I find it hard to participate in the economy in more adult ways. I won't be buying a house, car or having children anytime soon — even if I want to.

name: Melissa M.
quote: We now live in Mill Valley, but that is because my husband, myself and our two children could no longer afford to live on our own. We have moved in with my mother-in-law who owns her place outright. It is a two bedroom, but she has been incredibly gracious.
